NEW @nextbillionsecs "The Next Billion Cars - Hydrogen Vehicles: Liquid Dreams" With @SallydeMinx
on the future for hydrogen buses and trucks with H2X. @mpesce on working with ‘liquid’ hydrogen at -252º. @drewpasmith on Toyota's hydrogen implosion. https://t.co/aRyrsx9K0d

Researching for @nextbillionsecs series "The Next Billion Cars", @liubinskas and I drove an #EV from Sydney to the Hunter. No servo or service center charging along the way. At our destination, the charger _refused_ to charge our car -- because we weren't the right brand! Ugh. https://t.co/8EnVaqwHfA

And how Google looks to have lost. https://t.co/PbNXJqCLnH

NEW EPISODE of @nextbillionsecs "The Next Billion Cars - Electric Vehicles: Losing their Charge?" It's difficult to buy an EV you want, and Australia's charging infrastructure remains on the drawing board. Big changes needed. W/ @SallydeMinx & @drewpasmith https://t.co/W483s4tRmH

@V20_summit For that to work, there's going to have to be consensus both within the industry & within the various regulatory bodies - such as @FATFNews and @FinStbBoard, who are both joining us at @V20_summit this year - on how to frame responses on these difficult topics. It can be done.

@V20_summit These are points that large commercial organisations - such as banks - often struggle with. So it's not as though this problem will be sorted overnight. But there is a lot of space to provide guidelines, even standards, that comercial organisations can be expected to adhere to.

@V20_summit Since then @V20_summit - and the entire sector - has made good progress on making it easy to abide by those regulations.

This year, we have bigger things on our plate:

Probity.
Transparency.
Governance.

Unless you get those right, you get disasters like Luna & FTX. Guaranteed.

This is very on point because I'm at the #G20BaliSummit right now about to reprise my role as Session Chair of @V20_summit.

The topics three years ago - when we last met in person - centered on regulations to prevent money laundering and the financing of terrorism.

From what I've been hearing and seeing, it looks as though the USA is now tumbling into a vast-and-rapidly-mushrooming financial-political scandal that will be one for the ages.

@viveka i didn't mean to imply that you were, rather that mastodon does not itself know what it is therefore can not offer any guide on its use

a) Retiring to a monastery to live out my days as a mendicant Buddhist monk

b) Enjoying a social-media free lifestyle - which, tbqh, I have viz Facebook for nearly 13 years.

c) Mostly ignoring Twitter except when impossible not to.

Meanwhile, a clever person hacked together a decentralised Twitter equivalent sort-of-thingy...

USING GIT.

I am not making this up.

https://t.co/q3BXjhU5IC

@viveka "the way you want to use it"

Let's start _right there_, Viv.

Consider: I can download and install stable-diffusion-ui and instantiate a frickin GENERATIVE AI on my PC with about three clicks from download to pretty web interface.

And where's that for Mastodon? Why wasn't that the top priority for the Mastodon devs? Aren't users the point?

@viveka And this wasn't the first time I had a look. I've been looking since it launched in 2016, and it has not gotten any easier to install or use. 

That's... GIMP-level ignorance of UX.
@tims_pix Wait -- six years isn't patience enough?  How soon is now?

@viveka Yes it's been a week - and it's still only 0.27% of Twitter's users.

I had a good look this weekend, shuddered, and realised I would need to spend a day or more doing this. Which will happen in January, when I have time.

That's... for someone with tech chops.

Everyone else?

I'm calling this out not because I think federation and decentralisation bad ideas (they have both strengths and weaknesses, as centralisation does) but because this is going to have to change - and very quickly, because Twitter appears to be disintegrating at a rate of knots.
"OH BUT YOU CAN BUY HOSTING AT SIX USD A MONTH AND THEN POINT A CNAME RECORD AT IT" and at that point you've lost 99.63% of your audience, who have never heard of a CNAME record.

So what we've learned is that approximately 0.27% of all Twitter users have the necessary technical chops, the time, and the resilience to migrate to Mastodon.

To me that seems a rather big problem. It's been years. This should neither be this hard nor this obscure.

)

@V20_summit @FATFNews The @V20_summit builds bridges between the new world of virtual assets and the existing financial system. The final parts of that structure are now falling into place. Join us in Bali and help us complete this task in a way that creates benefits for all. 

https://t.co/KvZpBbnnIl

@V20_summit @FATFNews If you work with virtual assets - either as an exchange, a bank or regulator - we invite you to come to @V20_summit. This is the moment when conversation and engagement can lead to outcomes that deliver a successful integration of virtual assets into the global financial system.

@V20_summit @FATFNews It’s here in Bali that policies will begin to be formulated that will shape how virtual assets integrate with the global economy at scale over the next years. 

To be part of that conversation, you must be present at @V20_summit.

@V20_summit @FATFNews This is pretty much the last hurdle that needs to be cleared for virtual asset providers to be considered peers within the international financial system. It’s difficult to overstate how important this is. This is the key meeting of the @V20_summit.

@V20_summit @FATFNews This year @V20_summit is working with the FSB (Financial Stability Board). The FSB is focused on the safe integration of virtual assets with the global financial system. Via FSB rules virtual asset providers will gain access both to central banks and international banking system.

@V20_summit From the start, @V20_summit has been a way for the @FATFNews (Financial Activities Task Force) to be able to engage with virtual asset providers on issues relating to the prevention of money laundering, and countering international sanctions regimes.

@V20_summit Because of our successes, @V20_summit was ‘promoted’ into an official G20 meeting, in the ‘red zone’ in Bali’s Nusa Dua. That means it’s where all the leaders, finance ministers, etc, will all be gathered. V20 is taking place at the epicentre of geopolitical finance in 2022.
@V20_summit The @V20_summit serves a necessary and vital role, if we want regulations that are proportionate, to permit the broad integration of virtual assets into the global financial system.

@V20_summit When we started @V20_summit, there was nothing else like it. This is the place where the regulators meet with those they’re regulating, allowing each to understand the needs &  capacities of the other.

@V20_summit The @V20_summit brings virtual asset providers (crypto exchanges or banks that work with crypto, orgs that work with assets such as NFTs and tokens) with the relevant regulators for constructive discussions to make the industry safer and more successful for all participants.

We’re less than a fortnight away from @V20_summit - so let’s break down what it is, why it is, and who should plan on coming...

A thread... 🧵

@V20_summit @g20org As an official G20 event, @V20_summit takes place within the 'Red Zone' - where the G20 Leaders Summit takes place. Here, the leaders of the virtual assets industry will be able to gather and assess their progress on well-regulated integration within the global financial system.

We all know that will make this an incredibly fraught issue - politically, geographically, institutionally. It will bring additional pressure to almost every decision we make outside of our personal lives. And this will be the case for the rest of our lives.

8/fin

By the end of this decade it's almost guaranteed that a substantial portion of the nation's GDP will need to be dedicated to both the decarbonisation transition and dealing with the impacts of climate change. We'll pay and pay and pay for this. 7/

This is going to be incredibly expensive. I wish it were otherwise. These are those "hidden costs" of climate change that we have been warned about for many years. The bill has come due. And there's no real way to avoid the bill collector. It must be paid. /6

The pace of these events is accelerating. We need to plan - systemically, comprehensively, and quickly - so that we are not completely overwhelmed by climate changes that are already 'baked in'. We need to adapt, as best we can, and with all deliberate speed. Or fail. 5/

While I am not at all privy to what has been happening on the ground, it doesn't appear that much has been happening in the Northern Rivers nor in the Hawkesbury/Nepean to remediate  what have now become regular inundations. Failure to plan, etc. 3/

This new normal needs to be given an acknowledged priority in all community, state and federal planning. We need to be investing in whatever changes we require to live in a land of continued and accelerating climate extremes. We can't carry on as before. 3/

The climate has changed; adding energy to the climate system means more rapid and heavier rain falls, longer droughts, more instability. This is the new normal. It's no longer extraordinary. And while we absolutely need to work on transition, we also need to deal with this. 2/

@dwjperry but it's shielded -- it shouldn't be picking up *any* signals at all?

The tradies ran the coax to my aerial, and - voila! - I can now receive all of the digital channels. 

I can watch #AFLSwansCats tonight.  Which makes me very happy.

But no one really knows _why_ I could watch TV all those years, with a cable to nowhere.

#fin

Yet somehow - for almost eight years - I was able to receive the full range of television signals on a piece of shielded coaxial cable that wasn't connected to *anything at all*.

True, I'd lose the ABC every time it rained, but there's iView, so I never really gave it a thought.

When the antenna repair tradesmen came along this arvo to look at the problem, they followed the coax out of my house, up the side, through the roof, and then -- over to a long disconnected Foxtel Satellite dish.

My coax had never been connected to an aerial.

First I tried to diagnose the problem. I have way too many USB DVB-T tuners, and I tried them all on various computers.

None of them could get any sort of signal at all.

Just like my television.

Hmm.  So maybe the television isn't broken after all?

True story: During the very bad thunderstorm we had on the evening of Monday the 7th, my TV stopped receiving broadcast signals. 

I thought it had suffered a lightning strike, and fried that part of its circuits.

The truth turned out to be considerably stranger.

Interesting question here.  I _do_ remember Sharma saying this - echoing Scomo's attack on Labor's campaign points on EVs.

And I remember being very angry and disgusted and really wondering if any voter in Wentworth agreed with his claptrap.

His votes tell the real story.

If, instead, we'd gone all in on EVs - with tax rebates for vehicle purchases and construction of fast chargers at urban petrol stations, to make up for the lack of charging points - we might have seen EVs make up 10% of the passenger fleet. Instead, it's less than 1%. Own goal.

"Electric vehicles are a threat to the weekend." - Dave Sharma, 2019.

Keep that in mind next time you're filling your tank with petrol.

It was ridiculous at the time.

It's very nearly criminal now -- leaving the country unable to bear a petrol shock.

8/Until we have enough RATs to test pretty much every on-site employee pretty much every day, we can't really get things on an even keel both in terms of delivery of services and for the economy. We have to tread very carefully until that time.

7/With the exception of businesses that are 100% remote,  RATs aren't just a 'nice to have'. They're absolutely necessary to the functioning of the business & therefore a necessary business expense. We don't have enough in Australia to allow any services to operate smoothly.

6/Without downplaying the seriousness of a #covid19 infection - because even a 'minor' case can make you feel quite crook - it looks as though our high vaccination rates have helped us to reframe an infection more as an inconvenience than as a potentially life-threatening event.

5/Talking to the crew, most of them shared similar stories of taking things very carefully in the lead up to yesterday, lest they contract an infection and find themselves unable to work.

This seems to mark a change in how we think about a #covid19 infection.

4/When I showed up for my performance yesterday, I received another RAT and was overjoyed to receive my negative result - because I'd put myself into a personal 'lockdown' over the last week so as to not contract #covid19 - if I had, I would not have been able to work yesterday.

3/Inside all the crew - who had all been tested before entering the studio - all wore masks. We all noted that it probably wasn't necessary - but we all kept on wearing our masks just the same.

I only took my mask off when I was on stage for my rehearsal.

2/When I showed up for a rehearsal session on Friday morning, before I was allowed into the studio facility, I was given an on-the-spot RAT by a nurse, and waited patiently for 15 minutes until I received my result via text message (negative, thankfully).

Then I was allowed in.

1/Yesterday I did a big presentation for EY - broadcast to thousands of employees from a broadcast facility in the Inner West. So much so normal. But what wasn't normal (for me) were the COVID-safe protocols in place.

They show us what the next few months look like.
That's a lot of deaths. 😞

5/As the #omicron wave breaks & begins to subside, our forward planning horizon will extend from days to weeks, then months, & if we're very lucky with new #covid19 variants, even through to the end of the year. Right now, though, planning beyond this moment should be avoided.

4/This is an excellent moment to step away from planning, deferring decisions about anything that lies within an unrealised and largely unknowable future. That's not always possible, but to the degree that it is, this is the time to delay those decisions.

3/At present the whole world is in a period characterised by an overarching "intermittency" - systems are there, then they're not, they they're back. That's wreaking havoc with supply chains, delivery of healthcare services, and much else besides. Systems smashing into the wall.

2/Put succinctly, the 'forward planning horizon' - a timeline on which we situate our future actions and the expected actions of the world - becomes a brick wall across our path during the exponential growth of pandemic infections. Nothing is stable, nor can predictions be made.

1/Something that I first observed nearly two years ago that needs to be re-emphasised today: it is not possible to plan anything during the exponential growth phase of a pandemic -- except a path out of the exponential growth phase of the pandemic.

10/There is no real possibility of ending this outbreak. 

What we can do is to slow the pace of the outbreak, preserving our health care system so that those who need it during this crisis, have access to the best care we can offer them.

Be safe. 😷💉

9/FWIW I reckon this means:

Wearing a mask in all situations outside of the home, indoors and out.

Leaving home as little as possible until the current wave of infections has abated significantly.

Getting a booster shot as soon as you're eligible.

8/The only thing we as individuals can do right now is to 'flatten the curve' - think of it as an act of "personal responsibility". You are doing everything in your power to save our public health system for ourselves and for others who will need it in the future.

7/This means that the NSW Public Health system that emerges from this current onslaught of hospitalisations will be less able to meet the needs of the public in the short and quite probably the medium term.

It will likely take years to rebuild staff and experience.

6/A second-order consequence to remember is that the health care system is not just a finite resource - it is a consumable resource. People working within the system will be enduring stresses they have never before endured, added onto 2 years of pandemic stresse. Many will break.

5/A second first-order consequence is that those who need non-urgent but still vital hospital care - such as chemotherapy, ongoing treatment for chronic illnesses, and so forth, will also find the hospital system unable to meet their needs. We will be unable to care for the sick.

4/People who in ordinary circumstances would have survivable conditions may not survive because hospital resources do not exist in sufficient quantity to meet their needs at the time of their greatest need for them.

That's in a first-order consequence.

3/The immediate consequence of this is that people who need urgent treatment in hospital  - not just for #covid19, but for heart attack, stroke, and all sorts of traumas - will join at the end of a long queue of people who are also urgently needing treatment in hospital.

2/The public hospital system in NSW is already being pushed well beyond its normal operating capacities. We are only at the beginning of a vast wave of illness, and a corresponding vast number of people needing urgent hospital care. For some weeks to come things will get worse.

1/New South Wales is in a #covid19 emergency. That this is largely unacknowledged does nothing to alter this fact.

This is a good moment to review what is happening and what will happen as a consequence of what is happening now.

The good news is that because of vaccination, most of those folks hospitalised will not end up in ICU, on ventilators, or dying from #covid19.

But that also presumes they can get hospital care when they need it, to stabilise them.

Are we on that path?

The *entire* point behind the public health measure are to _flatten the curve_ so that the number requiring hospitalisation never exceeds available hospital capacity.

Honestly, I don't see us on that path at present.

We're heading toward an 'exponential omnishambles'.

If we are at 4000 cases a day by Christmas day - and again, that's on trend - that's another 300 fully vaccinated people hospitalised within the next ten days.

Every single day.

At that rate hospitals would be overwhelmed within a fortnight.

Look backward - it takes about 10 days between diagnosis and hospitalisation on average - and forward across projected cases - and you could project at least a thousand more people entering the system in the next 10 days.

Our NSW medical system broke during the first delta wave.

6/With all of this in mind let me suggest that the best possible Holiday gift we can give to ourselves and our loved ones is to do a #covid19 rapid antigen test before we attend any holiday gatherings.

That way we won't inadvertently ruin anyone's celebrations - or worse.

5/And I want to suggest that we are very much in this situation right now in Sydney, that our infection rates are currently going exponential and with only vaccination to protect us (that's not nothing, mind you) I don't think there's a clear upper limit in sight.

4/All of this is the sort of population dynamics and statistics that epidemiologists eat for breakfast. But what I think we're seeing in the data now is exactly the point where the effective infection rate R(eff) tips over past 1 infection per infected person & goes exponential.

3/As we're out-and-about this Silly Season, we're seeing more people, which lead to more casual contacts, more Delta infections, and when there are enough infections in the population sample, chances of meeting an infected person go from rarely to common.

2/Both around the 19th of August and now around the 4th of December when the positivity rate exceeded 0.37%, it has begun to climb quite rapidly. Exponentially, as it were.

One hypothesis is that this has to do with how often we'd likely run into an infected person.

1/Something I'm seeing in the data that I've been collecting from nearly the start of the Delta outbreak in NSW back in June is how the #covid19 test positivity rate correlates to exponential growth in case numbers.

There seems to be an inflection point somewhere around 0.37%.

This is exactly why the responsible athorities - in this case, the RBA, ASIC and APRA - can not absent themselves from the discussion around digital currencies nor their emerging use cases.

They can not be asleep at the wheel. That puts the whole of the financial system at risk.

And invoices that think, mortgages that think, employment contracts that think, sales receipts that think - on and on and on.

All of that paper, now static - just like paper money - develops its own interiority, and begins thinking.

Is that weird? Yes. Very.

But it's coming.

More siginficantly - this isn't just about money. It applies to all classes of assets.

Shares that think.
Loans that think.
Investment vehicles that think.
Super accounts that think.
A bill of lading that thinks.

Now you can begin how this touches every aspect of the economy.

This is not about improving payments. This is a fundamental re-visioning of what money is, wrought by transforming what money _does_.

Money has never had agency. Money has always relied on others to do things with it.

Digital currencies give money agency. 

'Money that thinks'.

Truth be told, there's no reason to believe payments in digital currencies would settle quicker than those via NPP - and in many cases, could take longer to settle.

That's far more than made up for by their exponentially expansive utility value as code+asset financial objects.

Six years ago the RBNZ said they didn't need a digital currency - because 'everyone has credit cards'.

That confusion between payment systems and the actual attributes of a digital currency is the first topic on which we need to establish clarity.

From clarity, onto action.

"The Reserve Bank has been unconvinced there is a need for CBDCs that could be used by consumers, pointing to the many other ways of making electronic payments."

If CBDCs were about payments, the RBA would be on point.

They are not - this is the essence of the policy failure.

"The government will examine whether Australia should adopt a central bank digital currency (CBDC) in the retail market, another recommendation of the inquiry chaired by Senator Andrew Bragg."

The Japanese are already there. Better late than never, tho.

This is a very commonly held belief of what is meant by a 'digital' currency. A payments network - which is what's being referred to here - is not the same thing as a digital currency. Payments networks crash. Digital currencies, like cash itself, can be wholly peer-to-peer.

@findercomau @TrustToken In all honesty I believe it would be a _very bad thing_ to have a privately-issued stablecoin become the de facto digital Australian dollar.

But that's where we are - right now - because of the continuing failures of the responsible bodies.

Ponder that.

I'll have more soon.

@findercomau @TrustToken That company @TrustToken, already has a "TAUD" - a digital Australian Dollar - that you can buy today, keep in a digital wallet, and freely convert for RBA-issued currency.  That's the whole point of a stablecoin.

And on my explorations yesterday I found at least one other.

@findercomau Where the regulator has refused to do their work - and that is manifestly the case here - the financial system is going to find every means within its power to route around it.

Hence Finder's stablecoin, which isn't even created by Finder, but by a company called @TrustToken.

@findercomau There's an obvious corollary to Gilmore's Law:

Financial systems regard regulators as damage and route around them.

However you feel about regulators (I rather like them) the financial system is _always_ routing around them. 

Hence regulators always have work to do.

@findercomau The RBA has failed.
ASIC has failed.
APRA has failed.

They have failed conclusively and comprehensively.

And because of that, there is an opening.

Recall Gilmore's Law:

The network regards censorship as damage and routes around it.

There are networks and there are networks.

@findercomau And because regulation takes time, that's why you get started *three years ago*, not at some to-be-determined date in the future after your tiny experiment in a wholesale digital currency which is really only an accounting convienence for the Big4 who don't have any need of it.

Y'all may not have noticed but yesterday @findercomau announced that they would be releasing a digital Australian Dollar - a 'stablecoin', in the parlance of this field, and make it available through their app.

This is a sign of a catastrophic policy failure at RBA, ASIC & APRA.

@fleurbrown @David_Speers @p_hannam Hydrogen is a portable fuel that can be used (almost) interchangably with existing fossil fuels. It's portable and can be stored, which is somewhat harder to do with electricity. Not impossible, just harder.  

Protons - hydrogen
Electrons - electricity

Both have their uses.

@fleurbrown @David_Speers @p_hannam Hydrogen, made by a 'hydrolyzer' (what we used to call electrolysis) using electricity made by renewables, is created without any emissions. It burns cleanly, producing water, not carbon dioxide.

It's not just that Carbon Capture and Sequestration has never succeeded at scale; it's that the economics for CCS are simply defeated by the collapsing costs of renewable energy. 

It is _already_ cheaper to do it emissions free than to capture emissions.

It's that simple.

Everyone in the Americas was 'immunologically naïve' to measles. So essentially everyone would have caught it. And it's so contagious it took very little time to spread across both American continents.

Although we don't have as much written evidence as we'd like, it's widely believed that a massive measles epidemic decimated the Americas -- before Columbus.

I want to draw everyone's attention to the Samoa Measles Outbreak of 2019. 

We don't think about measles  much - because everyone gets vaccinated. But Samoa let its vaccination levels fall, lost herd immunity -- and disaster.

Anywhere the Delta variant gets a foothold, it spreads so pervasively (R0 of 8 - 10) and so quickly (30 hours from exposure to infectiousness) that it simply denies any other variant any capacity to infect or transmit.

The variants are all competing against one another, as well as competing against our immune systems and our social distancing measures. These selection pressures (and probably some others) led to Delta's evolutionary success.

To do this, those infected need to produce a three-orders-of-magnitude greater viral load when infected. But they also need to do so as quickly as possible.

Unless a variant does both it could lose ground to another variant which only does one of them.

The Delta variant was the product of two distinct types of selection pressures:

1) It had to be so infectious that it could overcome social distancing measures that worked for the original strain

2) It had to outcompete other variants in infectiousness.

It achieves both ends.

12) Take care of yourselves; take care of the ones you love; and please, take care of all of us.

If you haven't, get vaccinated. 

If you know someone who hasn't been vaccinated, give them all the love they need to get them over the line.

And hang in there. We'll do this.

#fin

11) I am sure that we can get in front of this outbreak. I am sure that Sydneysiders can do something this hard. And I am sure that all of the rest of Australia will support us in this.

But it's hard yards ahead. 

And separated as we are, it's all the harder to feel the love.

10) We have a lot of work to do. 

First, to help people make it through this lockdown. Because we don't yet know how this ends. People are very afraid right now.

Second, to use this time to help people through their hesitancy, and get vaccinated.

9) We are going to need to love our way through this. And I don't mean that flippantly. 

I mean it's only the bonds and connections of love that can help someone through their hesitancy.

I know this from personal experience.

8) In Australia we have two problems: lack of supply and vaccine hesitancy. Not much we can do about the former, but we can do a lot about the latter. And I feel like that's where we have to be focusing our attention - and our love.

Because really that's what this is about.

7) Practically, this means VACCINATION IS NO LONGER OPTIONAL. 

I don't mean that governments should mandate vaccination. 

I mean it is up to all of us - as individuals, as communities, as leaders, AS A SPECIES - to see to it that everyone gets vaccinated AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE.

6) There's a plausible scenario - and again, I believe this is the path we're on, currently - where Delta mushrooms so quickly it overwhelms every nation almost before they know it. 

The vaccinated will largely survive that, unscathed. The unvaccinated will not fare as well.

5) As for the rest of the world, I am beginning to become deeply concerned. My gut is telling me that the Delta variant is on a trajectory to infect pretty much every single person on Earth - most of whom are not yet vaccinated.

It's already infected approximately 70% of India.

4) If we don't work out the correct set of measures very quickly - then immediately implement them without any major mistakes or resistance from the public - we could soon confront an epidemic of the dimensions we saw in the UK and the USA.

This is a life-or-death moment.

3) The restrictions that worked for Sydney with the original strain of the virus have failed to contain the Delta variant. We're still trying to find the right combination of measures to contain it. 

This is Pandemic 2.0: evolved, empowered and wildly infectious.

2) Sydney is tracking similarly to  Los Angeles and the US more broadly, which have seen case numbers double in the last fortnight. This is the story throughout almost all of the world, as this outbreak pushes nations back into greater restrictions.

1) Sydney is experiencing exponential growth in the number of #covid19 cases. On current trend, within two weeks we will be seeing ~250/day, then two weeks after that ~500/day. Truly terrifying numbers.

All despite a pretty severe lockdown.

Delta is very, very hard to control.

Ok folks, draw near.

It's time to take a look at what we know, what might happen from here, and what might be done about it.

As we had no #covid19 in NSW or VIC before these current outbreaks, we were able to capture the first person-to-person transmission of delta: just by sharing the same air at Bondi Junction. Add to that what we learned via The Crafty Squire: how rapidly people become infectious.

Given what we now know, even holding the line against Delta - which New South Wales appears to be doing - takes an enormous effort.

Right now, Sydney is getting around 100 new #covid19 infections per day.

Given that this is a war, and not just a battle, we have to build ourselves an industrial-scale munitions capability.

Vaccines.

We're already very good at that. So this is clearly doable. We need to be even better, and we need to do it with all deliberate speed.

We entered this year believing this was a sprint to a finish line of vaccinations.

Sadly, no. 

In war, each side learns from and adapts to its opponent.

We'll exit 2021 - we hope - drawing a line under the first major battle in what looks to be a long, drawn-out war.

This isn't about booster doses. This is about a virus that is continuing to evolve, and will continue to evolve until the pandemic is under control _everywhere_ on Earth.

Which, on current trend, won't be until at least last 2023.

More time, more variants.

Here's the thing: we need to consider the production of mRNA vaccines as a national security priority. We must immediately devote all necessary resources to this. We have about six months to do it, because that's how fast natural selection is throwing up new #covid19 variants.

#fin

14) While I am disappointed that our political leadership continues to sugar-coat the realities of the current situation, that should be no barrier for Sydneysiders making the necessary plans for what will be - at the very least - another month in lockdown.

It sucks, I know.

13) Melbourne spent as long (longer?) in lockdown. And came out. 

This will end, one way or another.

We will see the other side.

But it's very hard to say from here whether that's one month - or four.

So we need to plan for both the best and worst cases.

12) Given the availability of vaccine supply here in Australia, it will be at least some months before Sydney has 'ring vaccinated' itself into a "safe enough" situation that we could begin to roll back lockdown restrictions.  October, if we're lucky.

And hard to consider.

11) If we can not successfully suppress this outbreak, we will need to stay in lockdown indefinitely - or rather, until a sufficiently large number of Sydneysiders have been vaccinated that public health officials can adopt the strategy taken by Israel.

We know what that means.

10) I'm not saying it is impossible to suppress delta, only that the evidence suggests it is very hard to do so. That we have a lot of hard yards and hardship ahead of us, and the sooner we get our heads around that, the better we'll all fare.

And possibly, the sooner this ends.

9) At present we simply do not know whether we can suppress this outbreak. We are attempting something that - well, we just don't have a lot of successful strategies to rely upon with. Everywhere Delta has landed, it has gone on a rampage. It's as infectious as polio or smallpox.

8) Now the hard bits.

There are only two ways to exit this lockdown (the third way is apocalyptic and does not merit consideration)

a) We suppress the outbreak; or, 

b) We vaccinate our way out of this outbreak.

7) On Thursday I estimated this lockdown would end on 13 August. I now believe that is most optomistic date. A best case, it presumes everything goes exactly right from here, for the next five weeks.

That's moved from 'likely' to 'extremely unlikely' in my estimate.

6) Which means we need to be tightening the restrictions continuously - think of it as 'agile lockdown' - until we start to see a flattening of the curve. At that point, we start to have options.

At present, we do not have options.

5) The restrictions we have - however loosely observed in practice - haven't stopped the expoential growth of this outbreak. Possibly they slowed it a bit. But that's no longer the case. 

We need super-tight restrictions. We'll known in a week whether they're tight enough.

4) We will need to see a sustained run - probably a whole generation (14 days) of no unlinked cases and no cases in the community while infectious before anyone feels comfortable enough to loosen the restrictions we're currently experiencing.

We're far from that.

3) In the best case, we get in front of this outbreak. But as of today our unlinked case numbers and out-in-community-while-infectious case numbers are the highest ever.

And remember, this is COVID. All of that happened a week ago. We're seeing the past. During lockdown.

2) Will we get in front of this outbreak?  We have to remember that no polity (possibly Taiwan is an exception the jury still out on that) had gotten in front of a delta outbreak. 

A few nations can _endure_ one because of high vaccination rates.

But that's as good as it gets.

1) With the current exponential growith in #covid19 infections, there is no universe in which Sydney exits from restrictions next Friday. 

Or the following Friday.

Or the Friday after that.

On current trend, there is _no_ Friday when that happens.

*draws a deep breath*

Ok folks, draw near, because I am going to do my best to be very honest with you in this Tweetstream. I will say things out loud that we are all thinking -- but that our leaders are somehow unable to put into words.

Things that need to be said.

Now that we know this, we need to respect this knowledge. 

Mask up. Maintain your distance. Be super careful -- the Delta variant has all of the transmission qualities we feared in the original variant of the virus.

#fin

We can now _prove_ that the Delta variant can be spread simply by people breathing the same air - and they don't have to be particularly close together, either in space or time.

We suspected this, of course.

But with the Sydney outbreak, we now have proof of it.

Because there were _no_ other cases in the community, it was possible to observe the transmission events of the delta variant in a detail that was simply not possible in India or the UK or anywhere else - because there is so much virus present in those environments.

Now that Sydney is truly getting a look at the Delta variant, let's have a moment to understand _why_ that is:

It's because we are the first country in the world where the delta variant landed during an 'elimination' phase of the pandemic.

They don't last, but we do get them.

@KopoKopoInc Back in 2015, the payments and SME banking services available in East Africa had already far surpassed anything on offer here in Australia.

That appears to still be the case.

But hey, at least I was able to pay my barber using PayID!

#fin

One of these startups (@KopoKopoInc) went even further, and used analytics on the payments datastream provided by their customers to offer them lines of credit in keeping with their needs, at attractive interest rates because their cashflow had been so accurately modeled.

When I visited Rwanda in 2015, I learned that a whole ecosystem of startups had emerged to serve the needs of SBEs who wanted to accept M-PESA payments from their customers - and make them to their vendors.

It's an obvious thing, and these startups have done quite well from it.

Oddly enough, I've seen exactly this problem before.

In Kenya.

When M-PESA, the original mobile money project, launched there, it completely lacked merchant services. It was all about P2P payments. Utterly transformative, but not open to any business except a few utilities.

PayID is quite excellent for P2P transfers but completely lacks any merchant services. Hence, I was transferring to his personal account - which he noted by ringing it up on the til in his shop, to keep the accounting all accurate.

Which, let's be honest, is a poor solution.

@tiffanyshlain Could I do it every week? I don't know. Certainly it would lose some of its charge. It would no longer be quite so singular. On the other hand, my devices would also lose some of their compulsive potency. In that tug of war I would gain more space to be, uninterrupted.

This unplugging something my lovely friend @tiffanyshlain does every week with her family. It's something I should do far more often than once a year. But it's hard enough that it requires some corralling of the will, and a willingness to endure something weird and uncomfortable.

Those first few hours are _hard_, the time I would normally check all my feeds for the news of the day, check email, check twitter, and keep a constant slow drip of connectivity running through the background of my awareness.

Without that, I become intensely aware of my self.

We don't really like to talk about or even note weird compulsion to check in on our various devices (smartphones, smartwatches, and what have you) hundreds of times say. 

Taking them away creates the  necessary friction that helps them to be both visible and grants me agency.

On Good Friday for the past 3 years, I've practiced a day of complete unplugging. 

No devices.
No screens.
Nothing electronic or connected in any way.

It's a cleanse, of a sort, but - far more significantly to me - it brings me right up to the coalface of my device compulsions.

Meanwhile the idiot err elected president of Brazil says the economy is more important than the pandemic. 

At this point, we know definitively that the countries who dealt well with the pandemic saved their economies in the bargain.
For the first time since I started tracking it - exactly 4 months ago - the running 7-day average of daily US deaths from #covid19 has fallen below a thousand.

And then my dentist and all the other folks who take exceptional risks with their own exposure in order to make our lives more normal in this most abnormal of times can get the jabs to protect them and protect us.

It's not hard. 

Let's do this.

#fin

We need a solid communications plan, backed up by solid logistics. 

None of that is obviously in place.

It should have been in place before the first jab.

So let's start with that & the states can out there and do the job that the Commonwealth seems utterly unprepared to do.

At the current rate of 75K jabs per day, and a total of 50 million jabs to be delivered, well, you can see we'll be here around two years.

Now that obviously isn't going to happen, but it doesn't seem as though we're getting good enough fast enough.

We need to fix that.

We left containing COVID to the states.

That's largely gone quite well.

The Commonwealth said, "Leave the vaccines to us."

The PM bet his job on this.

And look at where we are.

Missed deadlines. No explanations. Just dissembling and misdirection.

It is time to point out - and call out - that the PM bet his job on a successful vaccine rollout.

That rollout is failing. Not because those panicky Europeans have stopped a few shipments.

Because a process that requires transparency & clear comms has got neither. Chaos reigns.

I say this as someone who is both an Australian citizen _and_ an American citizen. I’m happy our countries get along so well. 

At the same time, I recognise that they have independent interests, motives, goals - and cultures.

Our path must remain uniquely Australian.

So while this very public show of support may have lifted our spirits, where it goes, if it continues, leaves us so wedded to the American position, vis-a-vis China, that we can have no independent position of our own.

And we absolutely need that. For our own freedom.

We need to own our relationship with China. We can do that, and still maintain our close strategic coordination with the USA. 

Regional powers needn’t fall in line behind great powers - except where it suits their interest.

But we have to maintain some healthy boundaries.

And that’s _ok_.

That’s the way these things work - and have, for the entire duration of recorded history.  Great powers and regional powers. They always snipe. It’s the nature of power.

We can learn to live with it.

So long as we have the opportunity to manage it ourselves.

With friends like these, as the saying goes, we’ll have worse enemies that we want. 

We live, in a relative sense, next door to China. And that’s going ever going to change.

The US is a whole ocean away.

We are a regional power grinding against a new superpower.

Sparks fly.

While it might be reassuring to hear US Sec of State Blinken take Australia’s side in the recent trade tsuris we’ve been having with China, it is _not_ helping.

When the US makes our issues with China their issues with China, they deprive Australia of any capacity to respond.

Ok folks, draw near for a bit of a thread

About geopolitics.

Something much on my mind of late.

Because of the situation we find ourselves in here in Australia.

Caught between an unstoppable force in China, and an immovable object in the USA.

I haven’t been on Facebook for almost 11 years, so I have no idea how it will feel for a regular, heavy Facebook user.

So let us all know. Share with us your feels. Right now, that’s super important.

Because Australia may be on the cusp of an incredible discovery.

Nice, yes?

It feels as though the more we can focus on the connections with one another in a social network, the better they are for us. When we drag in external content - however well-intentioned - we dilute the connection that the whole reason to use a social network in the first place.

Australia’s news publishers will lose some inbound traffic, that’s for sure, and that’s the threat here from Facebook — but on the whole the Facebook experience could be come profoundly more sane, more connected - and more human.

Be nice, yes?

What if - and I know this may sound like crazy talk - but what if Australia’s Facebook users _prefer_ a feed that no longer has news in it? Something that harkens back to the original Facebook, where you stayed abreast of your friends and family and activities? Be nice, yes?

I do think that this day was always bound to come. 

In some ways it feels as though it was long overdue.

But the technology wasn't ready - and the need wasn't acute.

Now Platforms have, through their own actions, given birth to something they can not dominate.

Daoist dilemma.

This is the birth of the truly 'Dark Net. It wasn't about Silk Road or ordering your illegal drugs online. That was a sideshow. 

It's about creating a completely separate, invisible and for that reason largely unassailable cognitive space for a political counter-culture.

None of these new tools will immediately threaten existing networks of either capital or power.

They will take time to grow to scale. They will be buggy. They will be attacked.

Those attacks will tend, over time, to make these apps more resilient.

So they're not going away.

So we have a need for a network that can't be shut down by Apple, Google, Amazon - or anyone else - that is now meeting a whole new set of techniques designed to empower communities to work resiliently and highly effectively.

We are going to see a 'Cambrian Explosion' of apps.

And because of my work in the Australian startup community, I am regularly being pitched by startups who are using cryptocurrency technologies to create distributed, decentralised social networks.

Networks that are, by design, highly resilient and very difficult to monitor.

We've gotten extraordinarily good at writing peer-to-peer apps over the last few years - mostly because of everything we've learned working with cryptocurrencies and decentralised finance apps.

The state of the art is lightyears beyond where it was even a few years ago.

Every morning I check Hacker News (which is not for _those_ kinds of hackers, btw, but for people who practice the arts of programming), in which posts get voted to the top - and of course, this morning, several Parler alternatives have floated to the top 30.

They're all P2P.

Draw near, folks. 

I am not going to talk politics. It needlessly upsets me.

I'm going to talk Parler.

Because, twenty minutes ago, AWS shut it down.

https://t.co/uuYghJIwBK

You think that's an end to it?

I got news: that's not an end to it.

That's selection pressure.

My book is now available in the United States -- and my good friend @ken_goldberg has been helping to get out the word.

I'll have more to say - and share - about "Augmented Reality: Unboxing Tech's Next Big Thing" throughout the week.
